node.text:
Kendall hosts a special edition of Climate Talks in conversation with activists to amplify their work and learn from their experiences. 
In this episode, hear from @wawa_gatheru of @blackgirlenvironmentalist on how she copes with climate overwhelm and channels it into action. 

We’re so excited to launch this series with two of our favorites! And with an all star production team. Stay tuned for more. 

Credit:
Video editor @ecblackman 
Animation @meister_hq 
Creative direction @sydneyraehass 
Produced by @mahmo @steph_shep

node.text:
The ocean is rising and so are we! Last year, we asked @amandascgorman to collaborate with us on a poem for #worldoceanday and, a year later, her words are still inspiring us so we had to share it again with you.

Produced by @atmos @futureearth @lonelywhale 
Video by @ecblackman
Footage courtesy of @toritsui_ @brd_media @candace.crespi @danniwashington @georgemckenziejr @chrisleidyphotography

node.title: Ode to Our Ocean: A Poem by Amanda Gorman

node.text:
In 1990, Carl Sagan asked Voyager 1 to take a photo of the Earth upon its 6.4 billion kilometer journey back home. 

*Spoiler Alert* you have to watch the whole video to see it.

Caught in the center of scattered light rays (a result of taking the picture so close to the Sun), Earth appears as a tiny point of light, a crescent only 0.12 pixel in size.

Full text (cont’d in comments..):

“Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there--on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds.

Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.

node.text:
The new chair of the White House Council for Environmental Quality spoke with Steph on her day one in office about environmental justice, impact assessments, and how communities can get involved.

Conversation recorded on April 19, 2021. 

Credit: hosted by @steph_shep, produced by @mahmo and edited by @ecblackman; in collaboration with @whitehouse

node.text: It’s #climateday at the @whitehouse and we had the distinct honor of speaking with the legend herself, National Climate Advisor Gina McCarthy to unpack all of @potus’s climate executive orders announced in his first week! #climatetalk

node.title: Climate Talk @whitehouse National Climate Advisor Gina McCarthy

node.text:
“We will not march back to what was, but move to what shall be a country that is bruised, but whole, benevolent, but bold, fierce, and free. We will not be turned around or interrupted by intimidation because we know our inaction and inertia will be the inheritance of the next generation. Our blunders become their burdens. But one thing is certain, if we merge mercy with might and might with right, then love becomes our legacy and change our children’s birthright.”

This is for the books 🏆 ❤️ @amandascgorman

node.title: Amanda Gorman delivers the Inaugural Poem

node.text: Do you remember this video??? It was Released in 2003 by AlbinoBlackSheep, and my friends and I memorized it. Do I have issues with it in 2020? Definitely. But I’m always trying to retrace my exposure to climate change as a preteen, so watching this again gave me the chills!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by steph & max on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'IT'S TIME FOR GOOD NEWS TUESDAY 07.20.21 07 20.21 @FUTUREEARTH SWIPE THROUGH'.

node.text:
You know what time it is 🌎✨

Read more: you can access the links to articles in stories and highlights.

Credit: research by @chrstphr.schwng for @futureearth

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by steph & max on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'IT'S TIME FOR GOOD NEWS TUESDAY 07.20.21 07 20.21 @FUTUREEARTH SWIPE THROUGH'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 20, 2021 tagging @europeancommission. May be an image of text that says 'HEADLINE- EU drafts new set of climate regulations to help meet its pledge to cut emissions by 55% over this decade. The legislation presented by the EU's executive branch, the European Commission, encompasses about a dozen major proposals, including: phasing out of gasoline and diesel cars by 2035 new levies on gases from heating buildings an emissions trading program, under which companies pay for carbon dioxide they emit taxes on shipping and aviation fuels new infrastructure for alternative fuels increase capacity of EU's forests and other natural carbon sinks STORY 01 APNEWS.COM'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 20, 2021 tagging @unitednations, and @unbiodiversity. May be an image of text that says 'HEADLINE- UN drafts global framework to preserve and protect biodiversity. Eliminating plastic pollution, reducing pesticide use by two- thirds, halving the rate of invasive introduction and eliminating $500 billion of harmful environmental government subsidies a year are among the targets in a new draft of a Paris-style UN agreement on biodiversity loss. STORY 02 THEGUARDIAN.COM'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 20, 2021 tagging @irenaimages. May be an image of text that says 'HEADLINE- Global energy job market expected to grow dramatically as clean energy transition accelerates. The International Renewable Energy Agency's research towards a pathway of climate safety foresees the creation of up to 122 million energy-related jobs in 2050, more than double today's 58 million. It also has the potential to grow the world's economy by 2.4% over the expected growth within the next decade. STORY03 STORY IRENA.ORG'.

node.text:
“The difference between 1.5C, 2C or 3-4C average global warming can sound marginal. In fact, they represent vastly different scenarios for the future of humanity. 

The frequency of disasters, the survival of plants and animals, the spread of diseases, the stability of our global climate system and - ultimately - the possibility for humanity to survive on this planet hinge on these few degrees.

Today, we still have the chance to meet the 1.5C goal mentioned in the Paris Agreement. We can still protect ourselves from the worst climate impacts and begin to shape a healthier future. But we are rapidly approaching irreversible climate tipping points. 

This is why the climate conference #COP26 in November is so important for the global fight against climate change. Countries must conclude outstanding items regarding the implementation of the Paris Agreement and lay the ground for a transformational decade of climate action in the 2020’s.”

RP: @unclimatechange

node.text:
Kendall hosts a special edition of Climate Talks in conversation with activists to amplify their work and learn from their experiences. 
In this episode, hear from @wawa_gatheru of @blackgirlenvironmentalist on how she copes with climate overwhelm and channels it into action. 

We’re so excited to launch this series with two of our favorites! And with an all star production team. Stay tuned for more. 

Credit:
Video editor @ecblackman 
Animation @meister_hq 
Creative direction @sydneyraehass 
Produced by @mahmo @steph_shep

This quote from @zerowastechef hits every time: "We don't need a handful of people doing zero waste perfectly. We need millions of people doing it imperfectly."

Can you commit to one change that works for your lifestyle — maybe even improves it?!

Check out our guide to learn more of our favorite eco tips. 
Credit: series created in collaboration with @parley.tv for #PlasticFreeJuly

Photo by steph & max on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'COMMIT PLASTIC FREE STEP THREE Some more swaps for daily life, inspired by common forms of marine plastic debris. FOOD LAUNDRY Bring your jars and baggage to the market. Seek out bulk food refills and fresh produce. Better for you and your soul. Do less of it to limit microfiber pollution. And try detergent tablets, powder or concentrated liquids to cut plastic bottles. PERSONAL Shampoos, soaps, lotions... almost anything you need is now available in plastic-free bar form.'.

We need to rethink the system.'.

Frame it with the positives and they willl multiply. INSTEAD OF: "I SHOULD carry a reusable bottle because plastic makes me feel guilty." TRY! "I WANT To carry a reusable bottle because it cuts my waste down, saves me money, is better for my health, the planet's health *and* it keeps my beverage cold all day."'.

node.text:
MUST READ 🚨 “If you have ever thought of becoming more involved in the fight for climate justice, it’s time to stop thinking, and start doing.”

This whole article will get you heated. Link in stories. 

Credit: words by Emily Atkin via @heated.world designed by @mahmo for @futureearth

Photo by steph & max on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Fortunately scientists are also more confident than ever about how to improve the situation. In May, the influential and notoriously conservative International Energy Administratior (IEA) released a "bombshell" report outlining how the world could still achieve the Paris Agreement's goal of preventing a 1.5°℃ rise in global average temperatures. THE DIRE NEED TO SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASE FOSSIL FUEL USE, HOWEVER, HAS STILL NOT SUNK INTO THE MINDS OF THE WORLD'S BIGGEST POLLUTERS. Take the United UnitedState.... States... @FUTUREEARTH HEATED.WORLD'.
Photo by steph & max on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by steph & max on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Why is our government stalling? THE DRAFT IPCC REPORT PLACES THE BLAME DIRECTLY ON THE FOSSIL FUEL INDUSTRY. Specifically, "think tanks, foundations, trade associations and other third-party groups that represent fossil fuel companies for promoting 'contrarian' science that misleads the public and disrupts efforts to implement climate policies needed to address the rising threats. Rhetoric on climate change and the undermining of science have contributed to misperceptions of the scientific consensus, uncertainty, unduly discounted risk and urgency, dissent, and, most importantly, polarized public support delaying mitigation and adaptation action, particularly in the U.S." @FUTUREEARTH POLITICO:HEATED.WORLD'.

Photo by steph & max on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'A TRANSITION OF THE SCALE AND SPEED DESCRIBED BY THE NET ZERO PATHWAY CANNOT BE ACHIEVED WITHOUT SUSTAINED SUPPORT AND PARTICIPATION FROM citizens -IENT -IEA BLUEPRINT That means more than just saying you're for a healthy planet. It means taking a stand against the reason it's sick. @FUTUREEARTH HEATED.WORLD'.

Photo by steph & max on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The ability to participate in activism is a privilege. Many simply do not have the time, money, or emotional bandwidth to take on a global cause. Climate activism also has an unfortunate history of regressive finger-wagging, blaming relatively powerless individuals for not making "better" environmental choices. The climate activism needed today is not that type of activism WHAT'S Su TODAY IS outrage AT THE POWERFUL, BY THOSE WITH THE TIME AND RESOURCES TO EXPRESS IT. Especially since, according to the IEA, individual "behavior" changes will only account for around 4% cumulative emissions reductions the path to net zero. @FUTUREEARTH'.

Photo by steph & max on July 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'THE OPPORTUNITIES TO GET INVOLVED IN THE CLIMATE FIGHT ARE ENDLESS, AND THAT CAN BE OVERWHELMING BUT the beauty of people power ไS THAT YOU DON'T HAVE TO DO EVERYTHING. "You don't need to quit your job and become a climate activist. With enough people, one little thing every week, even a tweet, can make a huge difference." -GENEVIEVE GUNTHER, FOUNDER OF END CLIMATE SILENCE @FUTUREEARTH HEATED.WORLD'.

The bipartisan infrastructure deal Fossil fuel propoganda Fossil fuel projects (like pipelines) What you can do... Tweet at your Government Call your Senators Greentroll the fossil fuel industry Donate Join a climate protest Support climate science education and communication Start or join a campaign @FUTUREEARTH Sign a petition HEATED.WORLD'.

node.text:
"When you look at the diagram, it's a circle, and it represents the true cyclical nature of each change we experience. In the outside ring are the six sequential and predictable stages of change. 

The names of the stages: Loss, Doubt, Discomfort, Discovery, Understanding and Integration, indicate the primary experience of that stage. The inside pie pieces list the thoughts, feelings and behaviors most associated with the stage.

Change comes in all shapes, sizes, and intensities. It happens to all of us. Sometimes it sneaks up on us, sometimes it hits us over the head, sometimes we are lucky enough to choose when and how it happens. But it always happens. 

By integrating basic, positive attitudes and beliefs about change and combining them with the right skills (or tools), any of us can learn to adapt and grow in changing environments and situations. Is it easy? Not usually. Like any new activity or function, it takes a while to get used to it, but over time, we learn and integrate, and then do it without thinking. You can learn to better manage your life by managing the changes."

Credit: text from and graphic adapted from changecycle.com, designed by @bymatthewmiller for @futureearth

node.text:
There’s no better time to join the fight for climate justice. CHEERS!

Read more: you can access the links to articles in stories and highlights. 

Credit: research by @chrstphr.schwng for @futureearth

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by steph & max on July 13, 2021. May be an image of standing and text that says 'IT'S TIME FOR GOOD NEWS TUESDAY 07.13.21 07 @FUTUREEARTH SWIPE SWI THROUGH'.

Photo by steph & max on July 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'HEADLINE Byhalia pipeline canceled after environmental justice outcry. Pipeline opponents; environmental groups; and activists celebrated after the developers of the Memphis crude oil pipeline abruptly dropped the project. Developers cited market factors for the cancellation, but also had many legal and political obstacles, which gained national attention as an environmental justice ssue. ARTA OPROFIT PEOPLE OVER PROFIT STORY 01 EENEWS.NET'.

Photo by steph & max on July 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'HEADLINE Australian court says new coal mines must consider climate harm. An Australian court ruled that the country's environment minister has an obligation to children to consider climate harm as part of the decision-making in approving new coal mines. The federal court made the ruling in response to a class action suit brought by eight teenagers that argued the expansion of Whitehaven project in New South Wales would endanger their future. TTSOURFUTURE IT'S OUR RIGHT KEEP IT IN THE GROUND STORY 02 REUTERS.COM'.

Photo by steph & max on July 13, 2021. May be an image of fire and text that says 'HEADLINE- Natural gas is now banned from new construction in Berkeley, cA. A California district judge dismissed the California Restaurant Association's challenge. The ban, enacted in 2019, made natural gas illegal in new residential and commercial buildings. Roughly 27% of Berkeley's current greenhouse gas emissions come from natural gas use in buildings. The ban inspired laws in dozens of California cities, Washington state, Massachusetts, Oregon, New York and elsewhere. NATURAL GAS IS NOT GREEN STORY 03 EENEWS.NET'.

Photo by steph & max on July 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'HEADLINE- Canada names Mary Simon as first Indigenous governor general. Indigenous leader Mary Simon will be Canada's 30th governor general, becoming the first Indigenous person to hold the role in the country's history. "I can confidently say that my appointment is historic and inspirational moment for Canada and an important step forward on the long path towards reconciliation," she said. STORY04 STORY ALJAZEERA.COM'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 13, 2021 tagging @bp_plc, @shell, and @exxonmobil. May be an image of text that says 'HEADLINE- Oil companies are ordered to help cover $7.2 billion cleanup in Gulf of Mexico. Some of the world's largest oil companies have been ordered to pay part of a $7.2 billion tab to retire hundreds of aging wells in the Gulf of Mexico that they used to own, capping a case that legal experts say is a sign of things to come for future battles over cleanup costs. PAY UP STORY 05 WSJ.COM COM'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 13, 2021 tagging @phlcouncil, @phillythrive, and @hilco_redev. May be an image of text that says 'HEADLINE Two years after a huge refinery fire in Philadelphia, a new day has come for its long-suffering neighbors. The petroleum smell is gone, the benzene emissions are being monitored and residents in nearby neighborhoods of color feel they're finally being heard. The cleanup is a collaborative effort between Hilco Redevelopment, the city of Philadelphia, and local advocacy groups, requiring 50% minority participation at all levels of the redevelopment, involving everyone from workers to executives. STORY06 STORY INSIDECLIMATENEWS.ORG'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 13, 2021 tagging @blackrock. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'HEADLINE BlackRock secures $250m for climate projects in developing countries. The Climate Finance Partnership is designed to invest in climate solutions in emerging markets that will help communities that are most vulnerable to the impacts of the climate crisis. Investments are being prioritized across Asia, Latin America and Africa. STORY 07 EDIE EDIE.NET'.

Photo shared by steph & max on July 13, 2021 tagging @vainstituteofmarinescience. May be an image of text that says 'HEADLINE- HEADLINE World's largest seagrass project proves you can restore oceans. An environmental science team has been running the largest seagrass restoration project in the world in coastal bays off of Virginia's Eastern Shore. The 20-year project is a blueprint for restoring and maintaining healthy ecosystems, and proof that marine habitats can be brought back to life in a way that's self-sustaining. STORY 08 REASONSTOBECHEERFUL.WORLD'.

Photo by steph & max on July 13, 2021. May be an image of animal and text that says 'HEADLINE- China says giant pandas are no longer endangered. There are now 1,800 giant pandas living in the wild. a number that officials credit to the country's effort in maintaining nature reserves and other conservation initiatives in recent years. As a result, other species have also flourished: Siberian tigers, Asian elephants, and crested ibises have all seen a gradual increase in population numbers, according to China's Ministry of Ecology and Environment. STORY STORY09 09 NPR.ORG'.

node.text:
School Strike for Climate, Week 151

“We Africans contributed least, but are being affected most.”

Dr Asmamaw, a UK doctor from Ethiopia:

“Climate change is a crisis affecting the African continent more than any other. Desertification, changing weather and famine are becoming more and more frequent. The long history of slavery, colonialism followed by post-colonial policies have served to keep Africa trapped in poverty.”

“This makes their health systems fragile and the catastrophes they have suffered, include losing millions to the HIV pandemic, enduring several ebola outbreaks, only to now be going through the covid pandemic.”

The climate crisis is imminent and he called for the global north to listen to the voices from the global south and to work together.

Credit: RP @extinctionrebellion

node.text:
How to be Plastic Freeee! Learn the basics.
⁠
It's a complex issue to breakdown into 10 slides. We don't know everything but we know enough to know this shit sucks—it's gross, it's kinda scary, and it’s unjust.

Swipe through and then check out our guide to explore great posts on plastics from our friends around Instagram.

Photo by steph & max on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'LEARN PLASTIC FREE HEALTH Microplastics circulate the air and increase our exposure to toxic chemicals. And when plastics burn, they become more toxic. Plastic is literally everywhere in the air we breathe, the food we eat and the water we drink. Scientists have even found it inside our bodies. Most mind-blowing of all? Fossil fuel extraction and plastic production is set to increase drastically in the coming decades. 50,000+ bits of plastio are ingested yearly through contaminated products seafood and bottled water are the biggest culprits. Sources: Environmental Science & Technology; Shaw Institute'.

Photo by steph & max on July 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'LEARN PLASTIC FREE JUSTICE The way we make plastic and the way we dispose of it impacts minority communities. BATON ROUGE Cancer Alley, Louisiana. People living alongside refineries are exposed to high rates of air and water contamination, and they are getting sick. NEW ORLEANS The U.S., E.U. and Japan are the world's biggest plastic waste producers. Most of the plastic recycled in industrialized nations is exported to lower income countries, where it's more likely to leak into waterways and impact the health of Communities of Color. Sources: United Nations; Science Advances'.
